Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Symmetry Tests of Standard Model and Beyond via Light Meson Decays
Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this project is to test fundamental symmetries in the electromagnetic and strong interactions. By doing precise measurements of the properties of low-mass neutral mesons at Jefferson Lab, this research aims at understanding Nature by providing clues to some fundamental questions, such as: (1) Why are quarks confined inside of hadrons?; (2) What are the masses of the light quarks?; (3) Why is the observed universe dominant by matter over anti-matter?; and (4) What is dark matter? This project will also offer great opportunities to engage undergraduate students in cutting edge research. It will create a research-enriched learning environment, explore new approaches to recruiting prospective students, and develop new courses that are research-related.

The PI will play a leadership role as a spokesperson for the experiments: (1) completing data analysis of a precision measurement of the neutral pion lifetime; (2) optimizing and preparing an approved experiment to measure the radiative decay width of the eta meson; (3) commissioning and operating a new pair spectrometer in Hall D and taking data on eta-meson decay in parallel with the GlueX experiment; and (4) leading the development of the Jefferson Lab "Eta Factory" program. Measurements of various rare and forbidden decays of the eta mesons will provide sensitive probes for possible existence of new forces, which will extend our knowledge to the dark matter and explore new sources of CP violation needed to explain the matter and anti-matter asymmetry in the universe. The discovery of such new forces beyond Standard Model would have far-ranging implications to advance our understanding of nature.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Understanding the confinement properties of the Quantum Chromodynamics (QCD) and searching for new physics beyond the Standard Model (SM) are two frontiers in physics. The decays of three neutral pseudoscalar mesons (π0, η and η′) offer sensitive probes to address both fundamental challenges. With NSF support of this award, PI has been playing a leadership role (as a co-spokesperson) in three experiments to perform precision measurements of π0, η and ηꞌ at Jefferson Lab (JLab): (1) the PrimEx-II experiment (E-08-023) in Hall B on the π0 lifetime; (2)  the PrimEx-eta experiment (E-10-011) to measure the η radiative decay width in Hall D; and (3) JLab Eta Factory (JEF) experiment (E12-12-002A) to study η/ηꞌ decays with emphasis on rare neutral modes in Hall D. The activities from these experiments provided great opportunities to involve undergraduates in the cutting-edge research.

The PrimEx-II experiment was recently completed.  The result from this experiment,  "Precision measurement of the neutral pion lifetime", was published on Science, 368, 506-509 (2020), with unprecedented precision of 1.5% on the π0 radiative decay width. As the lightest and the simplest hadronic particle, π0 plays a crucial role in understanding the symmetries of QCD at low energy. The chiral anomaly drives the decay of the π0 meson into two photons with no adjustable parameters in the predicted decay width at the chiral limit. Over the past two decades, several independent theoretical calculations with high order corrections  reached ~1% precision and suggested about ~4% enhancement in the π0 decay width over the leading order anomaly prediction. The recently published final PrimEx result on the decay width of π0 into two photons achieved an accuracy of 1.5%. It confirms firmly the chiral anomaly and disagrees to the high order theoretical calculations with ~2σ significance. It raises fundamental questions about our understanding low-energy QCD and will have an important impact on the field.

The PrimEx-eta experiment on the η→γγ decay width measurement via the Primakoff effect is highly anticipated by the physics community. It will resolve a longstanding puzzle on the discrepancy (~3σ significance) between the collider measurements and the previous Primakoff measurement.  The result from this experiment will offer a crucial input for model independent determinations of the light quark mass ratio and the η-η' mixing angle. A 12x12 matrix of PbWO4 crystal calorimeter (CompCal)  was developed and constructed in 2018 to control the experimental systematics by measuring a well-known  Compton scattering on atomic electron. The first run was carried out in spring 2019 and ~50% of data on the 4He target (one of the two physics targets) was collected.   The second run has been scheduled for 2021.

The PI has been leading the collaboration in development of a high-resolution, high-granularity PbWO4 crystal insert to upgrade the existing forward calorimeter (called as FCAL-II) in Hall D, which is required for an approved JLab Eta Factory (JEF) experiment. Three prototype calorimeters were constructed for beam tests. The mechanical design of the PbWO4 module has been finalized. The detailed engineering drawings for the frame of the upgraded FCAL-II are currently in progress; and the final review of the design and technical drawings will be completed by fall 2020. The JEF experiment  will  measure the η/ηꞌ decays with emphasis on rare neutral modes. Precision measurements of SM allowed channels, such as η/ηꞌ→π+π-π0 , η/ηꞌ → π0γγ,  η/ηꞌ →γl+l-, will improve the light quark mass ratio determination, help understanding the scalar dynamics in the chiral perturbation theory, and provide inputs to calculate the hadronic light-by-light contributions to the muonic g-2. This experiment will also explore new physics beyond the Standard Model by searching for sub-GeV gauge bosons: a leptophobic dark vector boson (B′), hidden photon, hadrophilic scalar, and Axion-Like Particles, probing three out of four the most motivated portals coupling the Standard Model (SM) sector to the dark sector. The results from this experiment will have great potential to shed light on fundamental questions in important and emerging areas of nuclear/particle physics and cosmology: the origin and dynamics of QCD confinement, the anomalous magnetic moment of the muon, the nature of dark matter, and the mystery of asymmetry of matter-antimatter in the universe. 

The scope of this project, including both hardware development  and performance of the actual experiment, provided great opportunities for training undergraduates. Eight UNCW physics major students had directly worked on this project and spent at least two months at Jefferson Lab in the summer.  Two students wrote honor's theses based on their research results related to this project. Involvement of students in research also led student presentations at the university and several national conferences.  Students not only  made direct contributions to this project but also acquired significant technical skills in hand-on experiences, data analysis and computation, as well as advanced critical thinking and decision-making abilities.
